questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is on omeprazole for gastroesophageal reflux disease. She is now to be started on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel. You decide to switch to pantoprazole because of the action of omeprazole on which enzyme?
questions.solution:
Omeprazole is replaced with another proton pump inhibitor (PPI) during coadministration with clopidogrel because of the action on CYP2C19.

Clopidogrel is a prodrug that is activated to its active metabolite by the liver enzyme CYP2C19. Apart from CYP2C19, CYP3A4, and CYP2C9 are also involved to a certain extent.

Omeprazole serves as both substrate and inhibitor for CYP2C19. It may inhibit the activation of clopidogrel and decrease its antiplatelet action. Hence, they are not prescribed together.

questions.text: Zero-order kinetics means____.

choices.text: Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time.
Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time.
Fraction of administered drug reaching the systemic circulation
Time required for reduction of drug concetnration to half of its initial value

questions.solution:
In zero-order kinetics, the rate of elimination remains constant, irrespective of the drug concentration. It is capacity-limited elimination and only a constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time.

Examples of drugs eliminated by zero-order kinetics include (WATT Power)

    • Warfarin
    • Alcohol, Aspirin
    • Tolbutamide
    • Theophylline 
    • Phenytoin

The constant fraction of the drug is eliminated per unit time occurs in first-order kinetics (Option B).

The fraction of administered drug reaching the systemic circulation is the bioavailability of the drug (Option C).

The time required for the reduction of drug concentration to half of its initial value is the half-life of the drug (Option D).

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: A male patient weighing 50 kg has acute severe asthma, for which theophylline infusion is planned. The target plasma concentration is 10 mg/L. The volume of distribution of theophylline is  0.6 L/kg. What will be the loading dose in this patient for intravenous administration?
questions.solution:
The loading dose of theophylline in this patient for intravenous administration is 300mg. 

The loading dose is the amount or dose of a drug given to achieve target plasma concentration quickly when the treatment requires an immediate therapeutic response. It is usually given at the onset of therapy.

Loading Dose is given by the formula: 

Where, 

  • Vd - Volume of distribution (liters) 
  • Cp - target serum level (mg/L)
  • F - bioavailability factor

In the above patient, target plasma concentration (Cp) = 10 mg/L & volume of distribution (Vd) = 0.6 L/kg 

Hence, total Vd = 0.6 x 50 = 30 L

For intravenous route: F=1

Therefore, on substituting these values in the above equation,

Loading dose = 10 mg/L x 30L = 300 mg 

Note: The loading dose of 300 mg is usually not given as a single intravenous injection; it would be given as an infusion or as divided doses administered over a short period to reduce the toxicity associated with high plasma levels.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given dose-response curve?

choices.text: Drug B is the most potent.
Drug B is the most efficacious.
Drug C is more efficacious than drug D.
Drug A is more potent than drug B.

questions.solution:
The more the curve is on the left in a dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency. Hence, Drug B is the most potent.

Potency:

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • In the above image, the potency is Drug B> Drug A > Drug C > Drug D.

Efficacy:

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug. It reflects the capacity of the drug to activate a receptor and produce the response.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.
  • Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug C =Drug D > Drug B.
  • Drugs having a similar pharmacological effect can have different efficacies e.g furosemide and metolazone are both diuretics but furosemide has greater efficacy than metolazone.

questions.text: You read a news alert that mentions a novel drug has received marketing approval for diabetes mellitus and that it has shown positive results in a pivotal trial. The trial it passed corresponds to which phase of clinical trials?
questions.solution:
Phase III trials are usually considered pivotal trials and are necessary for the approval of the majority of drugs. 

Phase III trials, also called multi-site, pivotal or effectiveness trials are done for 3–5 years. It is a large randomized double-blinded comparative trial performed on patients with the target disease. It aims at establishing the value of the drug as compared to the existing standard of care.  When the initial Phase III trials are complete, the sponsor (usually a pharmaceutical company) applies to the FDA for approval to market the drug. This application is called either a New Drug Application (NDA) or a Biologics License Application (BLA).

Note: In some drugs related to rare diseases or malignancies, phase II studies are considered as pivotal trials and the drug may be approved on the basis of phase II studies.

questions.text: Dilator pupillae is supplied by______.

choices.text: Postganglionic sympathetic from cervical sympathetic chain
Sympathetic fibers of the fronto-orbital branch of the trigeminal nerve

questions.solution:
• Sympathetic distribution to the head and neck (vasomotor, pupil dilator, and pilomotor) is through the cervical sympathetic chain and its three ganglia.
  • Now, it looks a bit confusing. The sympathetic system is the thoracolumbar outflow, and here, the answer is the cervical sympathetic chain.
  • The outflow remains the same, the preganglionic fibers arise from upper thoracic segments but synapse in the cervical ganglia.

Related Pearl: Sympathetic and parasympathetic nerve supply to iris muscles

  • Dilator pupillae/radial muscle of iris: Sympathetic postganglionic nerves from cervical ganglion.
  • Constrictor pupillae/circular muscle of iris: Parasympathetic postganglionic nerves from ciliary ganglion (Edinger Westphal nucleus).

questions.text: Based on the data given - Heart rate in placebo (72) and drug (86);  SBP in placebo (110) and drug (128);  DBP in placebo (80) and drug (68);  Cardiac output in placebo (5) and drug (6). The action of the above newly tested drug is best related to ______.
questions.solution:
The action of the above-mentioned drug can be explained by the action of β1 + β2 agonists.

The parameters of the new drug when compared to placebo are:

  • Increase in heart rate
  • Increase in systolic blood pressure 
  • Decrease in diastolic blood pressure  
  • Increase in cardiac output

All the parameters of the new drug are compatible with isoproterenol which is a β1 + β2 agonist. Therefore, β1 + β2 agonism is the most appropriate answer. 

Options A and B - Heart rate is increasing with the drug whereas M2 agonism would result in a decrease in the heart rate. 

Option D - DBP is decreasing with the drug whereas α1 agonism would cause an increase in DBP.

questions.text: What is the scientific name of this plant whose roots & leaves were historically used in the treatment of asthma?
questions.solution:
The above plant is Datura stramonium, also called Jamestown or Jimsonweed.

The active ingredient in Datura stramonium includes anticholinergic alkaloids such as atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine. These were helpful in relieving the symptoms associated with asthma via inhibition of M3 receptors on bronchi, leading to a decrease in bronchospasm and tracheobronchial secretions. 

In India, the root and leaves of Jimsonweed were burned and the smoke was inhaled to treat asthma, though with great caution. Around the 1800s, British colonists observed the ritual and introduced the belladonna alkaloids in western medicine for the management of asthma.

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis in a patient with a dilated pupil not responsive to 1% pilocarpine?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate answer would be a pharmacological block. Antimuscarinic will occupy the receptors and results in non-responsiveness to pilocarpine.

In diabetic third nerve palsy, the dilated pupil is due to the loss of innervation to constrictor pupillae. Muscarinic receptors on constrictor pupillae will be intact resulting in miosis by pilocarpine.

In Adie's tonic pupil, there is denervation hypersensitivity. Pupil responds to even lower concentrations of pilocarpine.

Uncal herniation causes pressure on the third nerve leading to ipsilateral mydriasis. But muscarinic receptors are intact and thus the pupil responds to pilocarpine.

questions.text: A patient who is on anti-glaucoma therapy presents with corneal findings as shown in the image below. This finding is most commonly observed with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
The bilateral whorl-like pattern of cream-colored lines on the cornea seen in the image is called cornea verticillata or vortex keratopathy. It is observed with the use of netarsudil. It is usually mild and reversible and not associated with any significant visual abnormalities. 

Netarsudil is approved for lowering intraocular pressure in patients with open-angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension.

Other causes of corneal verticillata are: 

  • Fabry’s disease
  • Amiodarone
  • Chloroquine
  • Hydroxychloroquine
  • Indomethacin
  • Phenothiazines.

Brimonidine and apraclonidine can cause CNS depression and apnea in neonates and are contraindicated in children below 2 years.

questions.text:
The clearance of a drug which follows first-order kinetics (in one compartment model) is 0.2 L/min and volume of distribution is 40 L. What is the t1/2 of that drug?

t1/2: half-life
questions.solution:
The t1/2 of the drug would be 140 minutes.

Plasma half-life (t1/2) is the time required for the plasma concentration or the amount of a drug in the body to be reduced by 50%. It depends on its clearance and volume of distribution. 

t1/2 = 0.693 x Vd/CL

where, 

  • Vd - volume of distribution
  • CL - clearance.

In the given question, drug clearance (CL) = 0.2 L/min and Vd = 40 L

We can take 0.693 approximately as 0.7

Substituting,

t1/2 = 0.7 x 40 /0.2

t1/2 = 0.7 x 200

t1/2 = 140 minutes

Clinical implications: Half-life determines the duration of the drug effect. It also indicates whether the accumulation of the drug will occur under multiple dosage regimens, thereby making it is essential to decide on the appropriate dosing interval.

questions.text: The shortest acting calcium channel blocker is _______.
questions.solution:
• Clevidipine is a novel dihydropyridine available only for intravenous administration.
  • It has a very rapid onset of action (2–4 min) and a very short half-life (1–2 min).
  • It is metabolized by esterases in blood.
  • It is primarily indicated in the acute management of hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following does not increase the risk of digoxin toxicity?
questions.solution:
Digoxin toxicity is not increased by hyperkalemia.

In hyperkalemia, the ATPase alpha subunit is dephosphorylated, which is the binding site of digoxin. This reduces it's binding and effect. Therefore, hyperkalemia does not increase digoxin toxicity.

Factors predisposing digoxin toxicity: 

  • Hypokalemia (more digoxin binds to the Na+/K+ ATPase)
  • Hypercalcemia (increases the risk of arrhythmia)
  • Hypomagnesemia (Mg++ is a co-factor for Na+/K+ ATPase)
  • Renal failure (for digoxin)

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is usually avoided in a patient with myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
Aminoglycosides has to be avoided in a patient with myasthenia gravis. It blocks Ca2+ mediated exocytosis of acetylcholine from the presynaptic membrane in the neuromuscular junction. The decrease in ACh levels aggravates myasthenia gravis. 

Aminoglycosides can also have a direct inhibitory effect on post-synaptic acetylcholine receptors. 

Drugs that may aggravate myasthenia gravis are

  • Antibiotics like aminoglycosides, quinolones, and macrolides
  • Beta-blockers
  • Botulinum toxin
  • Local anesthetics
  • Magnesium
  • Non–depolarising muscle relaxants
  • Penicillamine
  • Quinine derivatives

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient who requires weekly hemodialysis is started on sevelamer. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Sevelamer is a phosphate binder indicated in chronic kidney disease.

Sevelamer is a nonabsorbable polymer that acts as a nonselective anion exchanger that lowers serum phosphate concentration. 

It is indicated to lower phosphate levels in patients with chronic kidney disease who are on dialysis. 

Note: Patiromer is a potassium binder approved for use in hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of bromocriptine_____
questions.solution:
Bromocriptine is an ergot derivative. Most of its action is due to agonist activity at D2 receptors. It also behaves as the partial agonist or as an antagonist of D1 receptor only in certain places of the brain.

Bromocriptine acts as a sympatholytic dopamine agonist and improves glycemic control

questions.text: The most frequent fracture site due to osteoporosis induced by glucocorticoids is_____.
questions.solution:
• Glucocorticoids preferentially affect trabecular bone and the cortical rim of vertebral bones.
  • Ribs and vertebra are the most frequent sites of fracture with glucocorticoids-induced osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic man on treatment presents with complaints of difficulty reading. Fundoscopy shows the following findings. Which antidiabetic drug class is likely to cause this?
questions.solution: The image shows diabetic macular edema, with hard exudates surrounding the blood vessels. It is a rare adverse effect seen with thiazolidinediones, and it resolves when the drug is discontinued.

questions.text: Insulin receptors belong to the following type of receptor
questions.solution:
Insulin action is transmitted through a receptor tyrosine kinase. 

Insulin receptors have 2 extracellular alpha subunits and 2 transmembrane beta subunits having intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity. 

Alpha subunits inhibit the tyrosine kinase activity of beta subunits; on the binding of insulin, there is a release of inhibition by alpha subunits and downstream signaling continues.

questions.text: A young lady who is on oral contraceptive pills refrains from taking any drug even for minor ailments due to the fear of contraceptive failure. Which of the following drugs can be taken safely?
questions.solution:
Among the given drugs, aspirin use is least likely to cause contraceptive failure.

Option B: Broad-spectrum antibiotics like tetracycline suppress the intestinal flora and interfere with the enterohepatic circulation of estrogen. This leads to lowering of plasma estrogen levels and can result in contraceptive failure.

Options C and D: Enzyme inducers like phenytoin and rifampicin increase the metabolism of oral contraceptives and can cause contraceptive failure.

questions.text: A neurology resident changed the current oral medication of a patient with Alzheimer's disease to a transdermal patch of a cholinesterase inhibitor. What must be the new drug that was prescribed?
questions.solution:
Rivastigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that is available as a transdermal patch for use in Alzheimer's disease. It can be applied for over 24 hours. Transdermal delivery reduces the fluctuation and avoids direct gastric irritation effects associated with oral formulations. 

Option A: Tacrine is an anticholinesterase that is obsolete because of its association with hepatotoxicity. 

Options B and D: Donepezil and galantamine transdermal formulations are under development and yet to be available in the market.

questions.text: A physician prescribes naltrexone to a patient undergoing treatment for opioid addiction. What is the function of this drug in opioid addiction?
questions.solution:
Naltrexone is used for the prevention of relapse in opioid addiction.

It is given only after initial opioid detoxification. The patient should be opioid-free for 7-10 days and have a negative naloxone challenge (no withdrawal after naloxone administration).

Naltrexone is a pure opioid antagonist which is more potent than naloxone. It is orally active and has a long duration of action which makes it suitable for opioid blockade therapy in post-addicts.

questions.text: Benzodiazepine-binding site on GABA receptor chloride channel complex is located at:

choices.text: Interface of alpha and beta subunits
Interface of alpha and gamma subunits

questions.solution:
Benzodiazepine-binding site on GABA receptor chloride channel complex is located at the interface of alpha and gamma subunits.

GABA binds at the interface of alpha and beta subunits. 

Types of subunits in the binding site determine pharmacological activity. Alpha 6 and gamma 1 type of subunits containing receptors have least affinity for benzodiazepines.

questions.text: The risk of carbamazepine induced Steven Johnson syndrome is increased in the presence of which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
HLA allele B-1502 is implicated as a marker for carbamazepine-induced Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis in Han Chinese, the USFDA recommends genotyping all Asians for the allele.

Note: The HLA B*1502 allele is seen in high frequency in many Asian populations other than Han Chinese, but there are few data on whether the allele is a marker for this severe outcome in anyone other than Han Chinese.

questions.text: A patient having both positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia was prescribed an atypical antipsychotic with partial D2 agonism. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
Aripiprazole is an atypical antipsychotic showing D2 partial agonism. It has a higher affinity for D2 receptors than for 5HT2A receptors.

As a partial agonist, aripiprazole has a dual-action which makes it useful in patients with both positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia.

Options A & D: Clozapine and risperidone are atypical antipsychotics with predominant 5HT2A antagonistic activity over D2 antagonism. 

Option B: Fluphenazine is a typical antipsychotic. They have predominant D2 antagonism property and such action on the mesocortical pathway may increase the negative symptoms of schizophrenia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding clozapine?

choices.text: More potently blocks D2 as compared to D1 receptors
Drug concentration is kept below 350ng/ml to avoid agranulocytosis
Should not be used along with carbamazepine
Should be discontinued if the neutrophil count is below 500/microL

questions.solution:
Agranulocytosis is an immune-mediated adverse effect and unlike seizures, it is not dependent on dose. Thus, agranulocytosis can happen at any plasma concentration of clozapine and concentration < 350 ng/mL does not lower the risk.

Option A: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic, which acts by blocking the 5HT2, α2 and D4 receptors. The potency of block is D4 > D2 >D1.

Option C: Concomitant administration of carbamazepine with clozapine is contraindicated because of the increased risk of leukopenia. In addition, carbamazepine is an enzyme inducer and reduces the half-life of clozapine.

Option D: Administration of clozapine requires regular blood count monitoring due to the risk of agranulocytosis. Monitoring is performed weekly for the first 6 months and once in two weeks for the next 6 months. Patients must be asked to report for evaluation in case of symptoms such as fever or sore throat. Clozapine should be discontinued if the neutrophil count drops below 500 cells/μL.

questions.text: A patient with a history of mania, on lithium therapy, is brought with complaints of vomiting and multiple episodes of diarrhea. On examination, coarse tremors and an ataxic gait are noted. What is the expected level of serum lithium in this patient?
questions.solution:
Clinical features are suggestive of lithium toxicity, where serum levels >1.5 mEq/L are considered toxic.  

Lithium has a narrow therapeutic index (0.8–1.2 mEq/L) and therefore requires monitoring to suspect toxicity. The toxic effects of lithium usually start manifesting when the serum level crosses 1.5 mEq/L.

Acute intoxication is characterized by: 

  • Vomiting
  • Profuse diarrhea
  • Coarse tremors
  • Ataxia
  • Coma
  • Convulsions.

A fine action tremor is common in patients taking lithium at therapeutic doses and can develop at any time during treatment. Therapeutic lithium tremor is generally symmetric, limited to the arms, and nonprogressive.Tremor from lithium toxicity is coarser and more disabling, may also affect the legs, and occurs with other symptoms of toxicity.

Serious effects of lithium toxicity will involve confusion, hyperreflexia, and seizures. Motor and cognitive side effects can become irreversible with persistent cerebellar tremor being the most common. 

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: Which of the following is not an adverse effect of salbutamol?
questions.solution:
Salbutamol in large doses can result in hyperglycemia, not hypoglycemia.

Option A: Tachycardia due to reflex sympathetic stimulation due to vasodilator action on β2 receptors and direct effect on cardiac β1 receptors (β2 selectivity is lost at high concentrations) 

Option B: Tolerance occurs due to desensitization on long-term use 

Option C: Hypokalemia due to direct effect on skeletal muscle uptake of K+ ions

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with Churg-Strauss syndrome is started on Mepolizumab. This drug acts against:
questions.solution:
Mepolizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IL-5. It is indicated in: 

  • Selected (eosinophilic phenotype) patients with severe asthma
  • Churg-Strauss syndrome 
  • Hypereosinophilic syndrome 

IL-5 plays a pivotal role in eosinophilic inflammation and is also involved in eosinophil survival and priming.

Monoclonal antibodies against IL-5 approved for asthma are:

  • Mepolizumab
  • Reslizumab
  • Benralizumab

The FDA recently approved a new indication for the drug Mepolizumab for adults and children aged 12 years and older with hypereosinophilic syndrome (HES) for six months or longer without another identifiable non-blood-related cause of the disease.

questions.text: Omalizumab is administered in bronchial asthma by which route?
questions.solution: Omalizumab is administered subcutaneously every 2-4 weeks. The dose is dependent on the circulating IgE levels.

questions.text: Thrombolytics can provide relative mortality reduction in the treatment of acute myocardial infarction if the patient comes within _____
questions.solution: Thrombolysis can provide mortality reduction for patients who present within 12 hours of symptom onset, especially in those presenting with STEMI and continued chest discomfort. However, maximum benefit is obtained if the patient can undergo fibrinolysis within 1-3 hours.

questions.text: A patient with a history of myocardial infarction has been on 75 mg aspirin OD for two years. The drug primarily acts by inhibiting which enzyme?
questions.solution:
Aspirin at low doses (75mg) primarily acts by inhibiting cyclooxygenase 1 (COX-1).

Low-dose aspirin, used for antiplatelet action, results in selective inhibition of platelet COX-1 (thromboxane synthase) inhibiting its ability to form thromboxane A2 (needed for platelet aggregation).

As platelets lack nuclei, new platelets have to be formed (life span of 7-10 days) for the return of COX-1 activity.

At higher doses (~1g/day), aspirin also inhibits COX-2 and results in decreased production of prostacyclin from endothelium. This may nullify the beneficial anti-aggregatory effect of aspirin.

questions.text: Absorption of iron is impeded by which of the following?
questions.solution:
The absorption of iron is impeded by egg-based foods. They contain a high amount of phosphates (egg yolk) that form complexes with iron and impede absorption.

Heme-based iron, present in meat products, is easily absorbed without the aid of a carrier and is not much affected by other foods. Inorganic iron is affected by several factors.

Factors increasing iron absorption are:

  • Reducing substances such as ascorbic acid and amino acids containing –SH groups - reduce ferric iron to the soluble ferrous form
  • Meat-based foods - enhance heme absorption and increase acid secretion.

Factors decreasing iron absorption are:

  • Phosphates, phytates, and tetracyclines - by forming complexes
  • Alkalies - prevents the reduction of ferric iron to the soluble ferrous form
  • Presence of other food in the stomach - by increasing pH

questions.text: Sargramostim is a recombinantly engineered analogue of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Sargramostim is a recombinant human GM-CSF (Granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor).

Indications for use:

  • Autologous bone marrow transplant - reduces the duration of neutropenia
  • Cancer chemotherapy - reduces the duration of neutropenia
  • Peripheral blood stem cell collection - to mobilize CD34 positive progenitor cells

It is administered subcutaneously or by slow intravenous infusion.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is used in the treatment of patients who develop severe thrombocytopenia following anti-cancer therapy?
questions.solution:
Oprelvekin is used in the treatment of thrombocytopenia secondary to anti-cancer therapy.

It is a recombinant human interleukin-11. Its predominant hemopoietic activity is the stimulation of megakaryocytopoiesis. Oprelvekin is indicated for the prevention and treatment of severe thrombocytopenia and the reduction of platelet transfusion requirements following myelosuppressive chemotherapy in patients with non-myeloid malignancies.

questions.text: Which is the anticoagulant of choice for the management of cancer-associated thromboembolism?
questions.solution:
The anticoagulant of choice for the management of cancer-associated thromboembolism is low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH).

It is the preferred agent because of more bioavailability, lack of need for anticoagulant monitoring, and a long t1/2. 

Venous thromboembolism (including deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and splanchnic vein thrombosis), is a frequent complication of cancer and is the second-leading cause of death in cancer patients receiving chemotherapy.

Based on the results from the Comparison of Low-molecular-weight heparin vs. Oral anticoagulants for long-term anticoagulation in cancer patients with venous Thromboembolism (CLOT) Trial, all recent guidelines now advise LMWH for cancer-associated thromboembolism. 

However, unfractionated heparin (UFH) can be used in patients with renal failure, and fondaparinux can be considered in patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

Tinzaparin (LMWH) is used for maintenance treatment in patients with cancer-associated venous thromboembolism.

questions.text: The oral thrombin inhibitor which can be used for prevention of stroke in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation is?
questions.solution:
The oral thrombin inhibitor which can be used for the prevention of stroke in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation is dabigatran. However, it is contraindicated in patients with mechanical heart valves.

Option B: Ximelagatran is also an oral thrombin inhibitor, but it has been discontinued due to the risk of hepatotoxicity.

Option C: Lepirudin is a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor used mainly in heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

Option D: Saxagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor used in the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A diabetic female patient on isoniazid and rifampicin for tuberculosis developed deep vein thrombosis. She was started on warfarin, but there was no elevation in prothrombin time. The next step should be?
questions.solution:
The next step should be using low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

The anticoagulant effect of warfarin is assessed by the measurement of prothrombin time (PT). Failure of elevation of PT indicates the decreased effect of warfarin. If we increase the dose of warfarin, it will take 5 days to prevent DVT. For immediate action, heparin or LMWH has to be started.

LMWH has more inhibitory activity on factor Xa than on factor IIa due to the conformational changes in antithrombin caused by the short molecules of LMWH. This conformational change the rate of factor Xa inhibition. LMWH has little effect on platelets. Heparin, LMWH, or fondaparinux are used in the treatment of deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, unstable angina, or acute myocardial infarction. Some of the examples of LMWH preparations are enoxaparin and dalteparin. The major adverse effect is bleeding and there is a low incidence of thrombocytopenia.

Other options:

Option A- Effect of warfarin starts in 4-5 days. Therefore, heparin or LMWH has to be started for immediate effect.

Option B- Acenocoumarin is also an oral anticoagulant. Its metabolism is also subjected to induction by rifampicin.

Option C- Rifampicin is an enzyme inducer and can decrease the effect of warfarin. Rifampicin is the most effective drug for tuberculosis and should not be replaced.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman had undergone modified radical mastectomy followed by chemotherapy with trastuzumab. She now presents with liver metastases. Which of the following drugs could be used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario depicts a case of trastuzumab-refractory breast cancer and lapatinib is used in this condition.

Drug Use
Lapatinib Refractory and metastatic breast carcinoma
Panitumumab Colorectal carcinoma
Erlotinib
  • Non small cell lung carcinoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
Imatinib
  • Chronic myeloid leukemia
  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumour

In 2018, Dacomitinib has been approved by FDA for the treatment of metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer. It is a selective and irreversible inhibitor of EGFR.

questions.text: Which antineoplastic drug is a peptide?
questions.solution:
• Bleomycin is a mixture of two closely related copper-chelating peptides, bleomycins A2 and B2, having potent antitumor activity.
  • It chelates copper and iron and produces superoxide ions, which cause oxidative damage to DNA, RNA, and proteins.

questions.text: Flagellate dermatitis is caused by _____.
questions.solution:
Flagellate dermatitis is caused by bleomycin.

Flagellate erythema/ dermatitis is characterized by multiple red, macular streaks of erythema on the trunk and limbs. The streaks are aligned in a criss‐cross pattern, giving a whip-like or flagellate appearance. They may be sore or pruritic. 

Flagellate erythema is seen in

  • A side effect of bleomycin chemotherapy
  • The toxic effect after consumption of shitake mushrooms
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Adult-onset Still’s disease
  • Docetaxel therapy

It is self-limiting and usually resolves within a few days to weeks. Topical steroids and oral antihistamines can be given to relieve the associated pruritis.

questions.text: A patient with Crohn's disease, refractory to steroid therapy is planned to be started on an anti-TNF alpha monoclonal antibody. Which of the following drugs does not belong in this class?
questions.solution:
Vedolizumab is a humanized anti-alpha-4-beta-7 integrin monoclonal antibody that prevents lymphocyte recruitment to the intestinal mucosa.

It is approved for use in moderate-severe Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

Anti-TNF alpha monoclonal antibodies indicated in IBD are: 

  • Infliximab
  • Adalimumab
  • Certolizumab pegol

questions.text: A patient of chronic low back pain has presented to your OPD with deranged LFT reports. He tells you he has been on long term treatment with a painkiller for his condition. Which NSAID has he most likely been taking?
questions.solution:
Diclofenac is the NSAID that has the highest risk of hepatotoxicity within the therapeutic dose.

Liver injury occurs in acetaminophen overdose but it is extremely rare in therapeutic dose. NSAIDs are not recommended in advanced hepatic and renal failure.

questions.text: NSAID that is more likely to reduce the antiplatelet effect of low dose aspirin
questions.solution:
The concomitant administration of ibuprofen and aspirin antagonizes the irreversible platelet inhibition induced by aspirin.

Ibuprofen impedes access of aspirin to the target Ser529 present on COX-1 in active platelets.

Thus, treatment with ibuprofen in patients with increased cardiovascular risk may limit the cardio protective effects of aspirin.

Unequivocal evidence exists for both ibuprofen and naproxen for the above interaction. Other non-selective cyclooxygenase inhibitors can also be invloved in such interactions. 

Options A and C: Etoricoxib and celecoxib are less likely to show the above drug interaction but confer a direct cardiovascular hazard due to their selective COX inhibition.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man was administered penicillin intravenously for Anthrax disease. Within 5 minutes, he developed generalized urticaria, swelling of lips, hypotension, and bronchospasm. The 1st choice drug to administer is
questions.solution:
Generalized urticaria, swelling of lips, hypotension, and bronchospasm suggests that the patient is developing anaphylactic shock. Epinephrine injection administered intramuscularly is the preferred choice in anaphylactic shock. Epinephrine is a powerful bronchodilator and it is a potent vasopressor.

Antihistamines have only an adjuvant role in anaphylactic shock and are not routinely used in emergency cases.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman complains of recurrent episodes of constipation and crampy abdominal pain for the last 4 months. The pain is relieved on defecation. After investigations, a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome with constipation is considered. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe?
questions.solution:
The drug used in irritable bowel syndrome with constipation is lubiprostone.

It is approved for chronic idiopathic constipation and constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (in female patients >18 years). It acts by stimulating Cl-channels in the intestine and increasing fluid secretion in the gut. This decreases the transit time.

Eluxadoline is an FDA-approved opioid drug for the treatment of diarrhea-predominant IBS in adults.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

questions.text: Mechanism of action of metoclopramide does not include ______.
questions.solution:
Mechanism of action of metoclopramide does not include 5HT4 antagonism.

Metoclopramide includes the following action:

  • 5HT4 receptor agonism
  • 5HT3 receptor antagonism
  • D2 antagonism
  • Sensitization of muscarinic receptors on smooth muscles

questions.text: The inhibition of hydrochloric acid secretion by omeprazole occurs within an hour, reaches a peak at 2 hours, and plateaus by the 4th day. After how many days will the secretion gradually normalize after stopping the drug?
questions.solution:
The secretion resumes normally in 3-4 days of stopping the drug when new proton pumps are synthesized.

Omeprazole after absorption enters into the systemic circulation, after which it diffuses into the parietal cells and accumulates in the acidic canaliculi.

Inside canaliculi, it is activated by proton catalyzed the formation of a tetracyclic sulfenamide that irreversibly inhibits H+/K+ ATPase.

Inhibition of HCl secretion occurs within 1 hour and reaches a maximum at 2 hrs.

The inhibition gradually increases over daily dosing and reaches a plateau after 4 days (80-98% inhibition).

The secretion resumes gradually over 3-4 days of stopping the drug when new proton pumps are synthesized.

questions.text:
The finding shown in the image below is seen as a side effect of which of the following drugs?
  1. Chloroquine
  2. Quinine
  3. Hydroxychloroquine
  4. Artesunate
  5. Lumefantrine
questions.solution:
The finding shown in the image is bulls-eye maculopathy, and chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine use are associated with this side effect.

Bull's-eye maculopathy refers to the ophthalmoscopic appearance of a central area of retinal pigment epithelial depigmentation surrounded by relatively normal retinal pigment epithelium, giving a bull's-eye appearance to the macula.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for scrub typhus?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline is the drug of choice for scrub typhus.

Azithromycin, chloramphenicol, or rifampin can be administered as alternatives in patients allergic to doxycycline and in pregnancy.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing orthopedic surgery. Which of the following first-generation cephalosporins can you use for surgical prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
The first-generation cephalosporin indicated for surgical prophylaxis is Cefazolin. It is the preferred agent for surgical prophylaxis when skin flora is the likely pathogen.

Cephalexin, cefadroxil, and cephradine are first-generation oral cephalosporins.

questions.text: Cilastatin is administered to prolong the action of _____.
questions.solution:
Cilastatin is administered to prolong the action of imipenem.

Imipenem is rapidly hydrolysed by the enzyme renal dehydropeptidase present. It is administered with cilastatin, a reversible inhibitor of dehydropeptidase to inhibit the breakdown and prolong the action of imipenem.

Other options:

Option B- Meropenem is not hydrolyzed by renal dehydropeptidase. Cilastatin administration is not necessary with meropenem.

questions.text: Non-convulsive status epilepticus is associated with the use of__________.
questions.solution:
Encephalopathy and non-convulsive status epilepticus have been reported with the use of cefepime. 

The mechanism of neurotoxicity in cephalosporin therapy involves inhibiting GABA-A release, increasing glutamate levels, and inducing the release of endotoxins and TNF-alpha, which is involved in septic encephalopathy.

questions.text: Drug of choice for hydatid cyst disease is ____________.
questions.solution:
Albendazole is the drug of choice for hydatid cyst disease due to Echinococcus granulosus.

Note: Albendazole has superior efficacy when compared to mebendazole against all tissue helminths because of its active metabolite albendazole sulfoxide.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with periorbital swelling as shown below. She complains of significant visual impairment and a fungal etiology is suspected. What is the most appropriate drug for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of invasive mucormycosis in the form of orbital cellulitis. Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection seen in patients with diabetes mellitus, leukaemia, lymphoma and other immunocompromised states. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza. 

Invasive mucormycosis has recently emerged as a life-threatening complication of COVID-19 in India. It is an opportunistic infection seen even in mild to moderate COVID patients with strong predisposing factors like hyperglycemia / uncontrolled diabetes. Diabetic patients receiving corticosteroids / immunosuppressants for COVID-19 treatment are exceptionally vulnerable to develop mucormycosis due to the risk of steroid-induced hyperglycemia.

questions.text: Which among the following is the Interleukin-5 antagonist indicated in the management of asthma?
questions.solution:
Reslizumab is a monoclonal antibody against interleukin-5 that is approved for use in severe asthma.

Option A & B: Omalizumab is an anti-IgE antibody and lebrikizumab is an antibody against interleukin 13, which are also indicated in the management of asthma.

Option D: Atezolizumab is an immune checkpoint modulator that inhibits the interaction of PD-L1 with PD-1 and B7-H1. It is approved for use in metastatic urothelial cancer and for NSCLC.

questions.text: Following agent is approved for use in ER positive and HER2 negative breast cancer
questions.solution:
Palbociclib is a cyclin-dependent kinase 4/6 (CDK-4/6) inhibitor indicated for the treatment of estrogen receptor (ER)-positive, human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-negative advanced or metastatic breast cancer.

Trastuzumab, pertuzumab, and lapatinib are indicated in HER2-positive breast cancer (Options A, B, and D).

questions.text: Sacubitril is a new drug approved for chronic heart failure. The mechanism of action of sacubitril is:
questions.solution:
Sacubitril is a neutral endopeptidase (neprilysin) inhibitor.

Sacubitril is a prodrug that is activated to sacubitrilat. It can inhibit the enzyme neprilysin (neutral endopeptidase), which is responsible for the degradation of atrial and brain natriuretic peptides (reduction of blood volume). Therefore, it increases the levels of atrial and brain natriuretic peptides and lowers blood pressure.

In 2015, the FDA approved the use of sacubitril in combination with valsartan, at a ratio of 1:1, for the treatment of chronic heart failure.

questions.text: Monoclonal antibody approved for use in Clostridium difficile infections is
questions.solution:
Bezlotoxumab is a monoclonal antibody against Clostridium difficile toxin B that neutralizes the toxin after binding it.

It is indicated for reducing recurrence of C. difficile infections in high-risk patients.

questions.text: A farmer presented with complaints of redness and excessive watering from the right eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals the following finding. Microscopy of the corneal ulcer scraping shows branched septate hyphae. Which of the following drugs can be used in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Slit-lamp examination showing a corneal ulcer with satellite lesions and a thick hypopyon are suggestive of mycotic keratitis (fungal corneal ulcer) while branched septate hyphae are seen with Aspergillus and Fusarium. Natamycin 5% suspension is the drug of choice in this condition.

Treatment of fungal corneal ulcer:

  • Topical antifungals: Aspergillus and Fusarium infections are treated with natamycin, amphotericin B and voriconazole while Candida infections are treated with nystatin.
  • Systemic antifungals: Ketoconazole or voriconazole may be needed if there is a severe corneal ulcer, perforated ulcer, or suspicion of endophthalmitis.

questions.text: Denileukin diftitox, a drug approved for the treatment of recurrent/refractory cutaneous T-cell lymphomas, is an immunotoxin made of:

choices.text: Fusion protein of IL-2 and pertussis toxin
Fusion protein of IL-2 and diptheria toxin

questions.solution:
Denileukin diftitox is an immunotoxin made from the genetic recombination of IL-2 and the catalytically active fragment of diphtheria toxin. 

It is indicated for advanced cutaneous T-cell lymphoma in patients with >20% of T cells expressing the surface marker CD25. After binding to the IL-2 receptors, it is internalized by endocytosis. The active fragment of diphtheria toxin then is released into the cytosol, where it inhibits protein synthesis through ADP ribosylation, leading to cell death.

Immunotoxins are proteins that contain a toxin along with an antibody that binds specifically to target cells.

Antibody-drug conjugates are complex molecules composed of an antibody linked to a biologically active cytotoxic (anticancer) drug. These antibody-targeted drug therapies are cell-specific to kill efficiently the target cells that bind and internalize the drug conjugate. Examples are:

  • Gemtuzumab ozogamicin - Monoclonal antibody against CD33 linked to a semisynthetic derivative of calicheamicin, a potent antitumor antibiotic. It was approved for the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia.
  • Brentuximab vedotin - Anti-CD30 IgG1 monoclonal antibody linked with the microtubule-disrupting agent MMAE. It is used for the treatment of Hodgkin and anaplastic lymphoma.
  • Ado-trastuzumab emtansine - It combines the HER2-targeted properties of trastuzumab with the antimicrotubule agent DM1 (derived from maytansine), allowing preferential intracellular drug delivery to HER2+ cells. It is used in the treatment of HER+ breast cancer.

questions.text: The drug cevimeline acts on which receptor for the expulsion of the secretions from the salivary gland?
questions.solution:
Cevimeline is a muscarinic agonist with affinity for both M1 and M3 receptors on the lacrimal and salivary glands.

While M1 activation results in increased secretion, M3 activation results in smooth muscle contraction and expulsion of the secretions.

Cevimeline has a long-lasting sialogogic action and may have fewer side effects than pilocarpine.

Cevimeline enhances lacrimal secretions in Sjögren’s syndrome. The usual dose is 30 mg three times daily.

questions.text: What does the area between the dotted lines in this graph indicate?
questions.solution:
The area between the dotted lines in the graph shows the therapeutic window. It is the range of steady-state concentrations of a drug that provides therapeutic efficacy with minimal toxicity.

The therapeutic index (TI) describes a relationship between the doses of a drug that causes lethal or toxic effects with the dose that causes therapeutic effects. It is also called the therapeutic ratio.

Mathematically, you can calculate TI by following way:

Therapeutic Index = LD50/ED50 (or) Therapeutic Index = TD50/ED50

Where,

  • LD50 (Median Lethal dose) is the minimum amount of drug that causes adverse effects in 50% of the population. LD50 could also be replaced with Toxic dose (TD50).
  • ED50 (Median Effective dose) is the quantity of a drug that can produce desired therapeutic effects in 50% of the population.

questions.text: Which of the following shows a U-shaped dose-response curve?
questions.solution:
Vitamins and essential metals show a U-shaped dose-response curve.

At a low dose, adverse effects are observed because there is a deficiency of these nutrients to maintain homeostasis. As dose increases, homeostasis is achieved, and the bottom of the U-shaped dose-response curve is reached. As the dose increases to surpass the amount required to maintain homeostasis, toxicity can ensue.

Thus, adverse effects are seen at both low and high doses. 

Hockey stick-shaped dose-response curve for toxicants that are also metabolic by-products. 

Inverted U-shaped dose-response curve for ligands that downregulate their receptors.

questions.text: Which of the following angiotensin receptor blocker has thromboxane A2 receptor antagonism effect?
questions.solution: Irbesartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker that is claimed to have thromboxane A2 receptor antagonism.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cardioselective beta blocker with antioxidant property?
questions.solution:
Nebivolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker with additional antioxidant property.

Nebivolol:

  • Nebivolol is a third-generation, long-acting, and highly selective β1 adrenergic receptor antagonist
  • It stimulates NO-mediated vasodilation via β3 receptor agonism
  • Nebivolol is approved for the treatment of hypertension
  • It has potential utility in the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
  • Nebivolol reduces oxidative stress and may have favorable effects on both carbohydrate and lipid metabolism
  • This can be used in metabolic syndrome.

Related Pearl: Cardioselective beta blockers: Mnemonic

Cardioselective Beta blockers Act At Nothing But Myocardium Exclusively.

  • B: Bisoprolol
  • A: Acebutolol
  • A: Atenolol
  • N: Nebivolol ( III )
  • B: Betaxolol ( III )
  • M: Metoprolol
  • E: Esmolol

( III ) - Third generation beta blockers. All the others are second generation beta blockers

questions.text: The schedule that deals with prescription drugs under the Drugs and Cosmetics Act is ______.
questions.solution:
Schedule H deals with prescription drugs. All the drugs listed under schedule H should be provided to the patient only with the prescription from a registered medical practitioner. 

All the drugs under the list must have the warning mentioned below, on their packaging listed prominently. 

"Schedule H drug. Warning: To be sold by retail on the prescription of a registered medical practitioner only" 

Schedule H1: To be sold on the production of a valid prescription, but the chemist will maintain a separate register where the identity of the patient, contact details of the prescribing doctor, and the name and dispensed quantity of the drug will be recorded. The dispensing quantity should be strictly according to the valid prescription. It is a recently introduced list with the objective of curtailing indiscriminate use of antimicrobials. 

Schedule X: To be sold with a valid prescription. Prescription in duplicate, separate license requirements, meticulous storage, and dispensing records must be maintained by the chemist. The drugs that have high abuse liability are included in schedule X.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male on multiple drugs presents with a round macule on his right leg for the last 7 days. The patient gives a history of similar episodes in the past which resolved spontaneously. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
This is a case of fixed drug eruption and the most likely cause is ibuprofen.

Fixed drug eruptions are characterized by sharply demarcated dull red to brown lesions. They occur in lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and cause a burning sensation. The lesion recurs in the same locations upon re-exposure to the offending drug.

Some of the drugs commonly known to cause fixed drug eruptions are Sulphonamides, NSAIDs, Analgesics, and Hypnotics.

Diagnosis is based on history and lesion morphology. Discontinuation of the offending drug is the first step in management.

Phenytoin and carbamazepine can lead to Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) and drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome).

Phase III trial, also called a multisite trial, is done for 3–5 years.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is a prostacyclin analog that can be added to the treatment regimen of a patient with pulmonary artery hypertension?
questions.solution:
Iloprost is a prostacyclin analog indicated in the management of pulmonary artery hypertension. It falls under the category of IP receptor (prostacyclin receptor) agonists.

Other drugs falling under the category of IP receptor agonists are:

  • Epoprostenol

  • Treprostinil

  • Iloprost

  • Selexipag

Option A: Sildenafil is a PDE-5 inhibitor. 

Option B: Misoprostol is a synthetic PGE1 analog. 

Option C: Dinoprost is a natural PGF2-alpha preparation. It should not be confused with dinoprostone which is a synthetic analogue of PGE2.

questions.text: You are planning to start treatment in a middle-aged man diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis. He has a history of chronic kidney disease and his current creatinine clearance is 25 mL/min. Which of the following drugs is least likely to require dose modification?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin is the least likely drug to require dose modification in renal failure patients as it is metabolized in the liver and primarily excreted in bile. 

In patients with renal failure, the half-life of isoniazid will be prolonged, but its adverse effects are not significantly increased. Hence dose modification is not usually done for isoniazid in clinical practice as a reduction in dose may render the regimen ineffective and increase the chances of resistance.

Ethambutol and streptomycin are primarily excreted unchanged through the renal system and need dose modification in renal failure.

This is a controversial question. Upon thorough review, we found that both rifampicin and isoniazid do not require dose adjustment. However, rifampicin would be the single best answer as it has a safer profile in CKD patients.

Mechanism of action

Bactericidal

Blocks mycolic acid synthesis.

Bactericidal (maximum)

Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis.

Bactericidal

Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane.

Bacteriostatic

Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.
